field_reports.description:
Yemen still reaps the shocks of heavy rain and flooding that hit several governorates of the country, causing many fatalities, infrastructural destruction, and movement of thousands of families. These floods started at the end of August 2024 and massively affected both urban and rural areas, including governorates like Al Hodeidah, Al Mahwit, Hajjah, Taiz, Al-Jawf, Ibb, Dhamar, and Ma'rib.

Severe climate-related events affected some 3,500 households between the 28th and 30th of August in Al Mahwit and Dhamar provinces, with 800 families displaced. This situation confirms the new challenges from climate change and increased vulnerability of Yemeni communities to freak weather occurrences. Floods have clogged most roads, bringing to a halt transportation of supplies. "The situation is dire, with no end in sight to the rainfall," said the U.N. Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs.

The human cost of the flooding has been immense. At least 38 fatalities were recorded in Milhan District, Al Mahwit, and at least 25 people have died in Wsab Alsafel District, Dhamar. Rescue and relief activities have been severely affected due to landslides and floods cutting across roads and separating already vulnerable communities. This comes after the destruction of infrastructure, including the collapse of homes and blockage of roads, which worsened the already dire humanitarian situation.

Disaster struck Al-Mahwit on August 28 after three strategically placed water reservoirs blew up into pieces. The first one, which was the largest and located on a mountainside, blew open first, which, in turn, caused the other two tanks to disintegrate below it. That chain of events even further endangered the local population by destroying homes and flooding the Wuljah market, an essential source of livelihood for so many people. Water contamination, the damage of health centers, and house destruction left hundreds of families stranded, taking refuge in temporary shelters and left to the task of rebuilding their lives.

Heavy rain and floods, since August 29, 2024, caused damage across the country of Yemen, affecting some of its governorates. Some 34,284 households are now affected by the floods, with large damage in some areas. The worst-affected governorate was Hajjah, where 18,380 HHs were affected, and Al Hodeidah, where 2,459 HHs were affected, with big damage reported. In Al Maharah, 2,293 houses were damaged and 1,838 houses in Hadramawt. Other affected Governorates include Ta'iz with 5,761 and Ma'rib with 2,524 houses damaged. The least affected are the Governorates of Ad Dali' (49), Amran (29) and Raymah (142).

Hundreds of homes have been destroyed either partially or totally, thus displacing families and leaving them without shelter. Besides the property losses, many households are losing livestock, further enhancing the economic burn of these already poverty-stricken communities. The floods affected 23 wells, which left the people without access to clean water—a very essential resource in such emergencies. This has equally resulted in the damage that has left vulnerable populations without access to medical care, hence deepening the humanitarian crisis.

The consequences of this flood would only multiply the sufferings of the communities affected all over Yemen. Displacement of families, water sources being contaminated, and the disruption of health services are among factors that urgently require both immediate and long-term humanitarian response. Sustainable interventions should be put in place to preclude future disasters of such scale, including, among others, rebuilding of critical infrastructure and addressing climate-induced vulnerabilities.

field_reports.description:
The recent heavy rainfall across multiple governorates in Yemen has resulted in severe flooding, causing extensive damage and displacing numerous families. The affected regions include Sa'dah, Hajjah, Al-Hudaydah, Taiz, Dhamar, and Amran Governorates. This report provides an overview of the impact and the ongoing response efforts coordinated by the Yemen Red Crescent Society.

In Al-Hudaydah Governorate, the severe flooding has led to the tragic loss of 30 lives, with 5 individuals still missing. The floods have displaced over 500 households, eroded large areas of farmland, killed numerous livestock and poultry, and rendered many roads impassable. The total number of affected households (HHs) is 5572, with significant impacts in districts such as Al-Maraweh (597 HHs), Zaydah (200 HHs), Al-qanawes (514 HHs), Zabid (250 HHs), Alhook (520 HHs), Al-Zuhrah (442 HHs), Sokhna (260 HHs), Al-dhahi (70 HHs), Al-Mina (50 HHs), Bait Alfaqeeh (190 HHs), Al-Lahiah (719 HHs), Al-Monirah (170 HHs), Al-hali (1300 HHs), Al-Jarrahi (110 HHs), Al-Meghlaph (180 HHs), and Al Durayhimi (150 HHs). There have also been reports of missing persons, including women and children, in areas such as Bilad al-Ruqud Zabid District, Village of al-Zain al-Qanawis District, and al-Lawiyah al-Duraihimi District.

In Hajjah Governorate, the flooding has affected 2050 households across various districts as YRCS branch data, including Al-shaghaderah (11 HHs), Rural Hajjah (18 HHs), Abs (1000 HHs), Kahlan Afar (27 HHs), Kaidina (519 HHs), Washhah (2 HHs), Wadrah (31 HHs), Bani Qais (206 HHs), Aslam (28 HHs), Hajjah City (18 HHs), Khairan Al Muharraq (160 HHs), and Aflah al-Yemen (30 HHs).The United Nations Population Fund-Yemen announced that the floods impacted more than 28,000 people living in four districts in Hajjah city.

In Taiz Governorate, heavy rains that fell on Maqbanah district resulted in the deaths and disappearance of 15 people. The floods swept away agricultural lands, roads, property, palm trees, and mango trees. The damage also included burying 87 hand-dug wells, damaging two artesian wells, sweeping away 50 pumps, and destroying six solar energy systems designated for the agricultural sector. Most of the main and secondary roads, agricultural lands, water resources including groundwater and surface wells, and citizens' properties have been severely impacted. Overall, the heavy rains have affected 2150 families across multiple sub-districts, leading to the demolition of some houses in Al-Harf Al-Dhahreen sub-district. Additionally, many valleys in the region were cut off, isolating communities and hampering rescue efforts. The natural disaster has inflicted severe damage on infrastructure and property.

In Dhamar Governorate, heavy rains have caused damage to several homes. 

In Sana’a Governorate, heavy rains have demolished several houses across various districts, including Arhab (2 houses), Bani Hushaish (5 houses), Hamdan (1 house), Al-Hayma Interior (2 houses), Sanhan (2 houses), Manakhah (1 house), and Al-Hayma external (3 houses). T

In Amran Governorate, rain has damaged 65 homes at Al-Muham camp in Raydah district. An emergency team has been deployed to assess and address the situation.

In Sa’dah Governorate, the heavy rains have affected 2000 families. 

Yemen's National Center of Meteorology has issued a warning of possible continuing rainstorms across the country, advising people to keep away from flood paths

field_reports.description:
Heavy rains and storms have caused widespread flooding across several governorates in Yemen. Initial assessments indicate significant damage to infrastructure, displacement of families, and livestock losses. Humanitarian organizations are mobilizing to respond to urgent needs, but access remains a challenge.

The affected areas are Hadramaut, Al-Jawf, Sana'a (including the capital city), Abyan, Al-Dhalea, Shabwa, and Taiz governorates, which have reported damage to homes, tents, and infrastructure.

The affected population is about  3,755 households (HHs), including both resident communities and Internally Displaced Persons (IDPs). Verification is ongoing, with the number expected to rise.

The affected governorates experienced damage to their roads, water sources, electricity networks, drainage systems, and agricultural land. The number of livestock casualties includes 87 sheep.

 Damaged roads are hindering access to some affected areas, hampering full damage and needs assessments.

 Continued heavy rain raises concerns about further flooding in the same or additional governorates.

There are needs in tents, non-food items, food, clean drinking water, and hygiene kits are the most critical needs.

Urgent Needs

  • Continued field assessments to fully understand the scale of the disaster.
  • Immediate provision of shelter, non-food items, food, water, and hygiene kits for affected families.
  • Repair or reconstruction of damaged infrastructure, prioritizing access roads and water sources.
  • Support for displaced families, including temporary housing and livelihood assistance.

field_reports.description:
Tropical cyclone TEJ made landfall over the southern coast of Al Mahrah Governorate on the night of 23 October and continued to move northwestward. On 24 October at 0.00 UTC, its centre was located about 20 km south of Al Ghaidah (Yemen) and 240 km west-southwest of Salalah (Oman).According to the media, some houses have been severely impacted, as well as roads and crops in Al-Mahra Governorate. In addition, interruptions of the communications and electricity networks have been reported.The authorities of Al-Mahra Governorate asked the citizens living in the affected areas to go to nearby shelters.TEJ is forecast to move further north-westward weakening and dissipating on 25 October. For the next 24 hours, more heavy rainfall is forecast over the Al-Mahra, Hadramout and Shabwa Governorates of Yemen and over the Dhofar governorate in Oman.( ECHO Daily Flash of 24 October 2023)

Large areas of Al Mahrah experienced heavy rain, flooding, and strong winds as a result of the cyclone since Monday morning.

A Yemeni family, consisting of 7 individuals, died in Al-Mahra Governorate after the collapse of their house in the Huswain District due to torrential floods resulting from the tropical condition Tej.

The cyclone also partially damaged many other homes and swept away large agricultural areas across Al Mahrah. Hundreds of families have fled to schools and shelters.There are now more 53 accomedation centers distributed over Al Ghaydah Al Masilah , SayhutHat and Shahan which are buildings and offices and Schools, Learning centers.

The number of affected HHs and individuals is 1711 HHs and 11977 individuals at Al Ghaydah Al Masilah Sayhut , Hat , Hsahan Districts.

A total of 400 shelters have been completely demolished, while 1311 have been partially destroyed.

The displacement of many families from the Al-Abri area, as well as Muhafeef and the neighborhood of Kalshat in Al-Ghaydah district, to hotels inside Al-Ghaydah district

Due to the strength of the winds, several residential water tanks flew into the air, along with some road regulations, many trees, and portions of older homes falling to the ground.

Needs:

Water points, latrines, and water tanks are urgently needed, as are NFIs, as well as food for the 1711 HHs. Cash assistance as well as psychological support are also needed.

The Yemeni Meteorological Center said that the tropical situation will continue during the upcoming hours with heavy rain across Al Mahrah and other eastern provinces, calling on local residents to take caution.

In Socotra , Heavy rains in the Socotra archipelago caused the displacement of dozens of families from the 14th of October neighborhood near the coast of Hadibo. Families affected by the floods were transferred to schools, and the rain and winds caused the closure of some roads as a result of the torrential rains washing away the dust, and a number of Farms were exposed to drift, and dozens of livestock died.  Earlier on On Sunday, there is one case of infection of a child after the door of their house fell on him in the district of Qalansiya and his condition is stable.  Rain, wind and high waves caused two fishing vessels to sink in the port of Hulaf, and there were no human casualties. The toll of damage so far is 314 houses completely damaged, 227 partially damaged , and two ferries / fishing boats were damaged, and two others drowned due to the cyclone.

In Hadramout , High waves and sea frenzy on the coasts of Corniche Mukalla and the branch will warn residents in Low-lying areas of the coast will be evacuated. An ambulance moves from the branch to the city of Mukalla to prepare and station to face any emergency matters. Yemen faces dire humanitarian conditions due to over nine years of war. Natural disasters exacerbate the suffering of millions in the country.

field_reports.description:
Extremely Severe Cyclonic Storm Tej is a tropical cyclone that formed over the central-south Arabian Sea and is currently threatening Yemen. 

As of October 21, Cyclone Tej is tracking west-northwestward in the Arabian Sea and is expected to make landfall west of the Oman-Yemen border.

The very severe cyclonic storm 'Tej' intensified into an extremely severe cyclonic storm and lay centred about 160 km east-southeast of Socotra (Yemen), 540 km south-southeast of Salalah (Oman), and 550 km southeast of Al Ghaidah (Yemen) at 8:30 am on Sunday.

Cyclone 'Tej', brewing in the Arabian Sea, intensified into an extremely severe cyclonic storm on Sunday and is headed towards the Yemen-Oman coasts .The cyclonic storm is predicted to move northwestwards and cross the Yemen-Oman coasts between Al Ghaidah (Yemen) and Salalah (Oman), close to the east of Al Ghaidah around noon on October 24 as a very severe cyclonic storm with wind speeds of 115-125 kmph, gusting to 140 kmph.

Due to the hurricane, two fishing vessels sank and large rock slides occurred in Socotra. During the past hours of today, Sunday, two fishing vessels sank in the port of the occupied Socotra archipelago due to the high waves resulting from Hurricane “Tej” that threatens the island.

Hurricane Tej began to adjust its path towards the west, falling between Al-Ghaydah and Sayhut in Al-Mahra Governorate, eastern Yemen.

field_reports.description:
Heavy seasonal rainfall since mid-March has caused flooding in many of Yemen’s governorates, affecting more than 18,000 families.

Floods have devastating effects on people. They cause loss of life, displacement, and damage to property and infrastructure. In Yemen, floods have caused severe damage to homes and infrastructure, including roads and bridges.

The heaviest downpours have damaged IDP shelters, crops, roads, and buildings in the governorates of Al-Jawf, Marib, Sayun, Hajjah, Amran, Marib, Shabwah, Lahj, Al-Bayda, Al-Mahwit, Taiz and Al-Mahra, leaving 31 people dead and more than 37 injured, nearly 1,000 buildings have at least partially collapsed.

In the March update, the OCHA in Yemen Said that “numerous governorates experienced heavy rains and wind, causing various degrees of shelter damage, destroying some homes. Based on the Information Management and Assessment Working Group’s (IMAWG) risk analysis, around 603,000 people in 112 districts are at high risk of floods this year. To date, 16,435 families have been affected. Out of the top 3 affected governorates, Marib has been the worst impacted, with 7,972 families affected, followed by Hajjah (2,228 families), and Amran (1,454 families). Yemen is prone to recurrent seasonal flooding which results in displacement, disruption to livelihoods, a spike in water-borne diseases, loss of crops, and property damage. In 2022, climate-related events triggered a 93 percent increase in new and secondary displacements, concentrated in Al-Hodeidah, Al-Jawf, Marib, and Ta’iz governorates. Torrential rains and flooding alone affected over 517,000 people and displaced over 170,000 people.”

The Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) of the United Nations reported 30 homes damaged in Salh district in Taiz governorate.

•          Areas in southern, central, and western Yemen have been affected by torrential rainfall in early April, causing floods and resulting in casualties and damage. This is the second time in a month that Yemen is hit by floods, affecting the already vulnerable population of

             Yemen. In mid-March, IDP-hosting sites in Marib Governorate were affected by floods.

•          According to the Global Disaster Alert and Coordination System (GDACS) and media, at least five people have died, including in Shabwah and Abyan Governorates. In addition, at least 30 houses have been destroyed or damaged in southwestern areas by flash floods, displacing people.

According to the Global Disaster Alert and Coordination System (GDACS) and media, at least five people have died, including in Shabwah and Abyan Governorates. In addition, at least 30 houses have been destroyed or damaged in southwestern areas by flash floods, displacing people.

In Al-Jawf governorate, based on the YRCS branch, Heavy rains fell in most of the villages and areas of the Al-Zahir district, which caused damage to the following areas: Al-Uqda, Rahban, Al-Harj, Al-Marafd, Husun Al-Shanan, Bin Jamaan village, Shamsan, Al-Raqaa, Tariq Center, and Al-Jashouba, as these areas are adjacent to the Red Mountain, from which torrents flow. The heavy rains continued for several hours, and the rains were repeated, because of which torrential rains flowed and several farms, lands, and homes of citizens were subjected to great damage and losses. Soil erosion, demolition, and flood waters entered several houses and destroyed others, in addition to the fact that there are several homes and lives trapped and isolated from the torrential rains, which made it difficult to reach them to limit the existing damages. fall of several houses and other damages, estimated at 9 mud houses completely damaged and 36 partially damaged, in addition to the damage and tearing of many tents, in addition to the exit of several families and they are leaving their homes for fear of the collapse of their homes because of the gathering and flow of torrents around them.

 

In the new agrometeorological early warning report from FAO which covered 1-10 May 2023 “In the past week, heavy rainfall continued to affect much of Yemen flooding fields and causing massive dam failures that led to the death of four people in Al Mahwit. Other areas that experienced heavy rainfall that led to submerged streets and homes damaged leaving behind devastation include central Ibb and much of the Highlands. More severe weather is forecasted, and several parts of the country are at risk of experiencing flooding from record rainfall events in the coming week. The expected floods are especially likely to affect over 5,000 people in Wadi Zabid (Al Hudaydah/Dhamar/Ibb), over 2,000 in Siham (Sana’a/Raymah/Al Hudaydah), and in Mour (Hajjah/Al Hudaydah), over 1,000 in Tuban (Lahj/Al Dhale’e/ Ibb), and in the north part of Wadi Harad (west Sadah), over 800 in Rimah (Raymah/Dhamar), and in Banna (Abyan/Lahj/Al Dhale’e), and about 700 in Sordud (Al Mahwit/Sana’a). Avoiding exposure to the hazard and implementation of contingency plans is strongly advised “.

field_reports.description:
In the period of this update (6-11 May 2023), Heavy seasonal rainfall has increased 4,142 HHs to the affected families to reach 24,142 HHs since mid-March.

People were badly affected by the floods. It leads to deaths, evictions, and destruction of infrastructure and property. Floods in Yemen have caused massive damage to homes and infrastructure, such as roads and bridges.

The heaviest rainfall has caused the flooding of Al-Jawf, Marib, Sayun, Hajjah, Amran, Marib, Shabwa, Lahij, Al-Bayda, Al-Mahwit, Taiz, and Al-Mahra governorates across the country. Shelters, crops, roads, and buildings were damaged. 39 people were killed, more than 41 were injured, and nearly 1,158 buildings at least partially collapsed. 

The meteorological center in Sanaa forecast rainfall across the country’s central and northern highlands in Saada, Hajjah, Dhamar, and other regions, advising residents to avoid traveling through and staying in flood courses. The same center issued a similar warning about excessive rainfall, inundation, and landslides in mountainous regions of the country.

Heavy rain and strong wind hit different parts of Al Qahirah and Al Mudhaffer Districts in Taiz Governorate. The rainfall lasted for many hours and generated floods that devastated residents' properties in nine sites. No human casualties were reported. The damages caused by rainfall and floods are 156 affected HHs, 85 partially affected shelters, and 71 completely affected shelters.

Heavy rain and strong wind hit Al-Sharayer Camp in Lahj Governorate. The rainfall lasted for many hours and generated floods that devastated IDP shelters on the site. No human casualties were reported until the moment of writing this report.  The damages caused by rainfall and floods are 82 affected HHs, and 82 completely affected shelters.

A small village, Al-Mehraq, in the Utmah District of the central province of Dhamar, was declared a disaster area after heavy rain and flooding devastated the area, killing one child and injuring several others, triggering landslides, trapping and displacing many families, and washing away farms and a flock of sheep.

field_reports.description:
Four people were killed and more than 84 families lost their homes in severe floods that struck the historic city of Tarim in Yemen.
The city, which is located in the center of Hadramawt governorate, is famous for its mud brick structures and home to more than 360 mosques including Al Mehdhar, which has the country's tallest minaret.
Tarim is a religious and academic center in Wadi Hadramout, with ancient mud buildings including mosques and palaces stacked together, and an old library with a collection of 14,000 religious manuscripts.

Heavy rain fell on Tarim, starting at 5 pm on Sunday, causing torrential floods, especially in Aideed, Al-Khalif and Damon.
Four people died, three of them from one family who were buried under the rubble of their home in Aideed
The torrents destroyed many old homes, and trapped scores of families inside their homes
A large number of people were injured while transporting the families of the displaced to mosques and public schools

The flood cut off all highways and bulldozed cars, and many families are still stuck in their homes.
Meanwhile, the Yemeni National Meteorological Center expected the continued heavy rains, calling on citizens to take shelter and not be in the corridors and valleys.
Road and mountain slope vehicle drivers should be aware of reduced visibility due to rain or fog.

According to the YRCS Sayoun branch Report, the number of new IDPs from the Marib governorate is 55 HHs.
the needs of these displaced families are concentrated in the fields of food, shelter, WASH.

field_reports.description:
Most areas of Marib are witnessing continuously armed conflicts daily, and this greatly affects the daily life of the population and the displaced (about 2.5 million displaced people), whether that destroys livelihoods or the displacement of people near conflict areas, all of this increases The difficulty of life for the vulnerable and poor groups in the region, and it greatly affects the psychological state of children and women.
According to the estimation of the YRCS Marib Branch, the number of new IDPs at Marib governorate reaches 1500 HHs, the needs of these displaced families are concentrated in the fields of food, shelter, WASH.
According to the YRCS Shabwah branch Report, the number of new IDPs from the Marib governorate is 142 HHs, and According to the YRCS Sayoun branch Report, the number of new IDPs from the Marib governorate is 55 HHs and According to the YRCS Sana'a Governorate Branch Report, the number of new IDPs from the Marib governorate is 59 HHs. 
Hospitals and health units face a great shortage in their medical supplies of medicines, equipment, and medical supplies. 
A state of fear and anticipation hangs over the residents of the city of Marib and the districts experiencing these conflicts in light of the continuing armed clashes.
field_reports.summary: The movement of IDPs from the Ma'rib governorate in Yemen

field_reports.description:
The GATI Cyclone may affect Socotra, Somalia, Yemen, and Oman west of the night [Sunday] to on Monday and possibly on Tuesday, with the main threat of heavy rains and flash floods.
Heavy rains are expected in Aden in the coming hours, according to the meteorological bulletin and warnings from the General Meteorological Authority.
The meteorology sector in Aden warned that the effects of the depression in the Arabian Sea would reach Socotra and the southern coasts during the next 24 hours, with heavy rains and disturbances in the sea.
The authorities and humanitarian workers must take all necessary measures to confront the possibilities of Aden being affected by the tropical depression, according to meteorological reports, in order to ensure that the disastrous consequences that occurred in the past and affected the camps for the displaced in both Aden and Lahj are not repeated.
field_reports.summary: Yemen Tropical Cyclone GATI-20
